page.title: 16TRANSPORT
page.content: In 1926 the railway line was opened, originally for passenger use and the odd freight came from Southampton or Esso Refinery. The passenger service did not last long because not many people used the train. Eventually it closed to passengers but the freight still carries on. Trains run quite frequently through picturesque scenes. The majority of the freight trains are tankers full of petrol ready to be taken away. The locomotives used on the line are either class 33's or 47's. The trains run about five times a day. First they set out from Esso, through a long cutting, across the level crossing, through an embankment and under the road bridge at Jones Lane. At Hythe the railway crossing man has got to open the gates when the trains come. He lives in the house next to the railway.
